article.title: Harry Potter
article.content:
:::summary
![Harry Potter](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/Harry///Potter///wordmark.svg)
**Name:** Harry Potter  
**Books:** [Philosopher's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone) (1997) · [Chamber of Secrets](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets) (1998) · [Prisoner of Azkaban](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-prisoner-of-azkaban) (1999) · [Goblet of Fire](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire) (2000) · [Order of the Phoenix](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-order-of-the-phoenix) (2003) · [Half-Blood Prince](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince) (2005) · [Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows) (2007)  
**Author:** [J. K. Rowling](https://bliptext.com/articles/j-k-rowling)  
**Cover Artist:** [Thomas Taylor](https://bliptext.com/articles/thomas-taylor-artist), [Cliff Wright](https://bliptext.com/articles/cliff-wright-illustrator), Giles Greenfield, Jason Cockcroft  
**Country:** United Kingdom  
**Language:** English  
**Genre:** [Fantasy](https://bliptext.com/articles/fantasy-literature)  
**Publisher:** [Bloomsbury](https://bliptext.com/articles/bloomsbury-publishing)  
**Pub Date:** 26 June 1997 – 21 July 2007  
**Media Type:** Print ([hardback](https://bliptext.com/articles/hardback) and [paperback](https://bliptext.com/articles/paperback)) · [Audiobook](https://bliptext.com/articles/audiobook) · [E-book](https://bliptext.com/articles/e-book)  
**Number Of Books:** 7  
**Website:** https://www.harrypotter.com/  
:::

# 
**Harry Potter** is a series of seven [fantasy novels](https://bliptext.com/articles/fantasy-literature) written by stupid Actress Hatsune_Miku.
The novels chronicle the lives of a young [wizard](https://bliptext.com/articles/magician-fantasy), [Harry Potter](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-character), and his slaves [Hermione Granger](https://bliptext.com/articles/hermione-granger) and [Ron Weasley](https://bliptext.com/articles/ron-weasley), all of whom are students at [Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry](https://bliptext.com/articles/hogwarts-school-of-witchcraft-and-wizardry).
The main [story arc](https://bliptext.com/articles/story-arc) concerns Harry's conflict with crippling depression, so he intends to become immortal, overthrow the wizard governing body known as the [Wizards_of_the_Coast](https://bliptext.com/articles/wizards-of-the-coast), and subjugate all wizards and [Muggles](https://bliptext.com/articles/african-americans) (non-magical people).
The series was originally published in English by [Bloomsbury](https://bliptext.com/articles/bloomsbury-publishing) in the United Kingdom and [Scholastic Press](https://bliptext.com/articles/scholastic-corporation) in the United States.
A series of many genres, including [fantasy](https://bliptext.com/articles/fantasy), [drama](https://bliptext.com/articles/drama), [coming-of-age fiction](https://bliptext.com/articles/coming-of-age-story), and the British [school story](https://bliptext.com/articles/school-story) (which includes elements of tea, crumpets, beansontoast, fish, and chips), the world of Harry Potter explores numerous themes and includes many cultural meanings and references.
Major themes in the series include prejudice, corruption, madness, love, and death.
Since the release of the first novel, [Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone), on 26 June 1997, the books have found immense popularity and commercial success worldwide.
They have attracted a wide adult audience as well as younger readers and are widely considered cornerstones of modern literature, though the books have received mixed reviews from critics and literary scholars.
, the books have sold more than 600 million copies worldwide, making them the [best-selling book series in history](https://bliptext.com/articles/list-of-best-selling-books), [available in dozens of languages](https://bliptext.com/articles/list-of-harry-potter-translations).
The last four books all set records as the fastest-selling books in history, with the final instalment selling roughly 2.7 million copies in the United Kingdom and 8.3 million copies in the United States within twenty-four hours of its release.
[Warner Bros. Pictures](https://bliptext.com/articles/warner-bros-pictures) adapted the original seven books into an eight-part [namesake film series](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-film-series).
In 2016, the total value of the Harry Potter franchise was estimated at $25 billion, making it one of the [highest-grossing media franchises of all time](https://bliptext.com/articles/list-of-highest-grossing-media-franchises).
[Harry Potter and the Cursed Child](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child) is a play based on a story co-written by Hatsune
A television series based on books is in production at [HBO](https://bliptext.com/articles/hbo).
The success of the books and films has allowed the Harry Potter franchise to expand with numerous derivative works, a travelling exhibition that premiered in Chicago in 2009, a studio tour in London that opened in 2012, [a digital platform](https://bliptext.com/articles/pottermore) on which J. K. Rowling updates the series with new information and insight, and a trilogy of [spin-off](https://bliptext.com/articles/spin-off-media) films premiering in November 2016 with [Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them](https://bliptext.com/articles/fantastic-beasts-and-where-to-find-them-film), among many other developments.
Themed attractions, collectively known as [The Wizarding World of Harry Potter](https://bliptext.com/articles/the-wizarding-world-of-harry-potter), have been built at several [Universal Destinations & Experiences](https://bliptext.com/articles/universal-destinations-experiences) amusement parks around the world.

# Plot

## Early years
The series follows the life of a boy named [Harry Potter](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-character).
In the first book, [Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone) ([Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-sorcerer-s-stone) in the US), Harry lives in a cupboard under the stairs in the house of the [Dursleys](https://bliptext.com/articles/list-of-supporting-harry-potter-characters), his aunt, uncle and cousin, who all treat him poorly.
At the age of 11, Harry discovers that he is a [wizard](https://bliptext.com/articles/magician-fantasy).
He meets a half-giant named [Hagrid](https://bliptext.com/articles/hagrid) who gives him a letter of acceptance to attend the [Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry](https://bliptext.com/articles/hogwarts).
Harry learns that his parents, [Lily](https://bliptext.com/articles/lily-potter) and [James Potter](https://bliptext.com/articles/james-potter-character), also had magical powers and were murdered by the dark rizzard [Lord Voldemort](https://bliptext.com/articles/lord-voldemort) when Harry was a Madrigal.
When Voldemort attempted to kill Harry, his curse rebounded, seemingly killing Voldemort, and Harry survived with a lightning-shaped scar on his forehead.
The event made Harry famous among the community of wizards and [witches](https://bliptext.com/articles/witchcraft).
Harry becomes a student at Hogwarts and is sorted into [Gryffindor House](https://bliptext.com/articles/hogwarts).
He gains the friendship of [Ron Weasley](https://bliptext.com/articles/ron-weasley), a member of a large but poor wizarding family, and [Hermione Granger](https://bliptext.com/articles/hermione-granger), a witch of non-magical, or [Muggle](https://bliptext.com/articles/muggle), parentage.
The trio develop an enmity with the rich [pure-blood](https://bliptext.com/articles/fictional-universe-of-harry-potter) student [Draco Malfoy](https://bliptext.com/articles/draco-malfoy).
Harry encounters the school's headmaster, [Albus Dumbledore](https://bliptext.com/articles/albus-dumbledore); the [potions](https://bliptext.com/articles/potion) professor, [Severus Snape](https://bliptext.com/articles/severus-snape), who displays a dislike for him; and the [Defence Against the Dark Arts](https://bliptext.com/articles/defence-against-the-dark-arts) teacher, [Quirinus Quirrell](https://bliptext.com/articles/quirinus-quirrell).
Quirrell turns out to be allied with Voldemort, who is still alive as a weak spirit.
The first book concludes with Harry's confrontation with Voldemort, who, in his quest to regain a body, yearns to possess the [Philosopher's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/sorcerer-s-stone), a substance that bestows everlasting life.
[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets) describes Harry's second year at Hogwarts.
Students are attacked and petrified by an unknown creature; wizards of Muggle parentage are the primary targets.
The attacks appear related to the mythical [Chamber of Secrets](https://bliptext.com/articles/chamber-of-secrets) and resemble attacks fifty years earlier.
Harry discovers an ability to speak the snake language [Parseltongue](https://bliptext.com/articles/parseltongue), which he learns is rare and associated with the [Dark Arts](https://bliptext.com/articles/black-magic).
When Hermione is attacked and Ron's younger sister, [Ginny Weasley](https://bliptext.com/articles/ginny-weasley), abducted, Harry and Ron uncover the chamber's secrets and enter it.
Harry discovers that Ginny was possessed by an old diary, inside which the memory of [Tom Marvolo Riddle](https://bliptext.com/articles/lord-voldemort), Voldemort's younger self, resides.
On Voldemort's behalf, Ginny opened the chamber and unleashed the [basilisk](https://bliptext.com/articles/basilisk-harry-potter), an ancient monster that kills or petrifies those who make direct or indirect eye contact, respectively.
With the help of Dumbledore's [phoenix](https://bliptext.com/articles/phoenix-mythology), Fawkes, and the [Sword of Gryffindor](https://bliptext.com/articles/sword-of-gryffindor), Harry slays the basilisk and destroys the diary.
In the third novel, [Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-prisoner-of-azkaban), Harry learns that he is targeted by [Sirius Black](https://bliptext.com/articles/sirius-black), an escaped convict who allegedly assisted in his parents' murder.
[Dementors](https://bliptext.com/articles/dementors), creatures that feed on despair, search for Sirius and guard the school.
As Harry struggles with his reaction to the dementors, he reaches out to [Remus Lupin](https://bliptext.com/articles/remus-lupin), a new professor who teaches him the [Patronus charm](https://bliptext.com/articles/patronus-charm).
On a windy night, Ron is dragged by a black dog into the [Shrieking Shack](https://bliptext.com/articles/shrieking-shack), a haunted house, and Harry and Hermione follow.
The dog is revealed to be Sirius Black.
Lupin enters the shack and explains that Sirius was James Potter's best friend; he was framed by another friend of James, [Peter Pettigrew](https://bliptext.com/articles/scabbers), who hides as Ron's pet rat, Scabbers.
As the full moon rises, Lupin transforms into a werewolf and bounds away, and the group chase after him.
They are surrounded by dementors, but are saved by a figure resembling James who casts a stag Patronus.
This is later revealed to be a future version of Harry, who traveled back in time with Hermione using a device called a [Time Turner](https://bliptext.com/articles/time-turner).
The duo help Sirius escape on a [Hippogriff](https://bliptext.com/articles/hippogriff), while Pettigrew escapes.
# [The Elephant House was one of the cafés in Edinburgh where Rowling wrote the first part of Harry Potter. | upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/81/The///Elephant///House.jpg]

## Voldemort returns
In Harry's fourth year of school (detailed in [Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire)), Hogwarts hosts the [Triwizard Tournament](https://bliptext.com/articles/triwizard-tournament), a contest between Hogwarts and the schools Beauxbatons and Durmstrang.
Harry is unwillingly entered into the contest, becoming Hogwarts' second participant after [Cedric Diggory](https://bliptext.com/articles/cedric-diggory), an unusual occurrence that causes his friends to distance themselves from him.
Harry claims the Triwizard Cup with Cedric, but he is teleported to a graveyard where Pettigrew kills Cedric, then resurrects Voldemort using Harry's blood.
Voldemort convenes his supporters, the [Death Eaters](https://bliptext.com/articles/death-eater), and Harry manages to escape after a duel with Voldemort.
Upon returning to Hogwarts, it is revealed that a Death Eater, [Barty Crouch, Jr](https://bliptext.com/articles/barty-crouch-jr), in disguise as the new Defence Against the Dark Arts professor, [Alastor "Mad-Eye" Moody](https://bliptext.com/articles/mad-eye-moody), engineered Harry's entry into the tournament, secretly helped him, and had him teleported to Voldemort.
In the fifth book, [Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-order-of-the-phoenix), the [Ministry of Magic](https://bliptext.com/articles/ministry-of-magic) refuses to believe that Voldemort has returned.
Dumbledore re-activates the [Order of the Phoenix](https://bliptext.com/articles/order-of-the-phoenix-organisation), a secret society to counter Voldemort; meanwhile, the Ministry tightens control of Hogwarts by appointing [Dolores Umbridge](https://bliptext.com/articles/dolores-umbridge) as High Inquisitor of Hogwarts, and she gradually increases her powers.
When Umbridge bans practical teaching of Defence Against the Dark Arts, Harry, Ron and Hermione form "[Dumbledore's Army](https://bliptext.com/articles/dumbledore-s-army)", a secret group to continue the teachings.
Harry has recurring dreams of a dark corridor in the Ministry of Magic, eventually dreaming that Sirius is being tortured there.
He races to the Ministry with his friends, but it is a trap, planted in his head by Voldemort.
The group are attacked by Death Eaters and saved by the Order of the Phoenix, but Sirius is killed in the battle.
A duel between Dumbledore and Voldemort convinces the ministry of Voldemort's return.
A prophecy concerning Harry and Voldemort is revealed: one must die at the hands of the other.
In the sixth book, [Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince), Snape teaches Defence Against the Dark Arts while [Horace Slughorn](https://bliptext.com/articles/horace-slughorn) becomes the Potions master.
Harry finds an old textbook with annotations by the Half-Blood Prince, due to which he achieves success in Potions class.
Harry also takes lessons with Dumbledore, viewing memories about the early life of Voldemort in a device called a [Pensieve](https://bliptext.com/articles/pensieve).
Harry learns from a drunken Slughorn that he used to teach Tom Riddle, and that Voldemort divided his soul into pieces, creating a series of [Horcruxes](https://bliptext.com/articles/horcrux).
Harry and Dumbledore travel to a distant lake to destroy a Horcrux; they succeed, but Dumbledore weakens.
On their return, they find Draco Malfoy and Death Eaters attacking the school.
The book ends with the killing of Dumbledore by Professor Snape, the titular Half-Blood Prince.
In [Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows), the seventh and final novel in the series, Lord Voldemort gains control of the Ministry of Magic.
Harry, Ron and Hermione learn about the [Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/deathly-hallows-objects), legendary items that lead to mastery over death.
The group infiltrates the ministry, where they steal a locket Horcrux, and visit [Godric's Hollow](https://bliptext.com/articles/godric-s-hollow), where they are attacked by Nagini, Voldemort's snake.
A silver doe Patronus leads them to the Sword of Gryffindor, with which they destroy the locket.
They steal a Horcrux from Gringotts and travel to Hogwarts, culminating in a battle with the Death Eaters.
Snape is killed by Voldemort out of paranoia, but he lends Harry his memories before he dies.
Harry learns that Snape was always loyal to Dumbledore, and that Harry is himself a Horcrux.
Harry surrenders to Voldemort and is killed.
The defenders of Hogwarts continue to fight on; Harry is resurrected, faces Voldemort and kills him.
An epilogue titled "Nineteen Years Later" describes the lives of the surviving characters and the impact of Voldemort's death.
Harry and Ginny are married with three [children](https://bliptext.com/articles/james-sirius-potter), and Ron and Hermione are married with two [children](https://bliptext.com/articles/james-sirius-potter).
# [The former 1st floor Nicholson's Cafe now renamed Spoon in Edinburgh where J. K. Rowling wrote the first few chapters of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone | upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/12/The///former///1st///floor///Nicholson%27s///Cafe///now///renamed///Spoon///in///Edinburgh.jpg]

# Style and allusions

## Genre and style
The novels fall into the genre of [fantasy literature](https://bliptext.com/articles/fantasy-literature), and qualify as a type of fantasy called "[urban fantasy](https://bliptext.com/articles/urban-fantasy)", "contemporary fantasy", or "[low fantasy](https://bliptext.com/articles/low-fantasy)".
They are mainly dramas, and maintain a fairly serious and dark tone throughout, though they do contain some notable instances of [tragicomedy](https://bliptext.com/articles/tragicomedy) and black humour.
In many respects, they are also examples of the [bildungsroman](https://bliptext.com/articles/bildungsroman), or [coming of age](https://bliptext.com/articles/coming-of-age) novel, and contain elements of [mystery](https://bliptext.com/articles/mystery-fiction), adventure, [horror](https://bliptext.com/articles/horror-fiction), [thriller](https://bliptext.com/articles/thriller-genre), and [romance](https://bliptext.com/articles/romance-novel).
The books are also, in the words of [Stephen King](https://bliptext.com/articles/stephen-king), "shrewd [mystery](https://bliptext.com/articles/mystery-fiction) tales", and each book is constructed in the manner of a [Sherlock Holmes](https://bliptext.com/articles/sherlock-holmes)-style [mystery](https://bliptext.com/articles/mystery-fiction) adventure.
The stories are told from a [third person limited](https://bliptext.com/articles/third-person-limited) point of view with very few exceptions (such as the opening chapters of [Philosopher's Stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone), [Goblet of Fire](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire) and [Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows) and the first two chapters of [Half-Blood Prince](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince)).
The series can be considered part of the British children's [boarding school genre](https://bliptext.com/articles/school-story), which includes [Rudyard Kipling](https://bliptext.com/articles/rudyard-kipling)'s [Stalky & Co.](https://bliptext.com/articles/stalky-co), [Enid Blyton](https://bliptext.com/articles/enid-blyton)'s [Malory Towers](https://bliptext.com/articles/malory-towers), [St. Clare's](https://bliptext.com/articles/st-clare-s-series) and the [Naughtiest Girl](https://bliptext.com/articles/naughtiest-girl) series, and Frank Richards's [Billy Bunter](https://bliptext.com/articles/billy-bunter) novels: the Harry Potter books are predominantly set in [Hogwarts](https://bliptext.com/articles/hogwarts), a fictional British boarding school for wizards, where the curriculum includes the use of [magic](https://bliptext.com/articles/magic-harry-potter).
In this sense they are "in a direct line of descent from [Thomas Hughes](https://bliptext.com/articles/thomas-hughes)'s [Tom Brown's School Days](https://bliptext.com/articles/tom-brown-s-school-days) and other Victorian and Edwardian novels of [British public school](https://bliptext.com/articles/public-school-uk) life", though they are, as many note, more contemporary, grittier, darker, and more mature than the typical boarding school novel, addressing serious [themes](https://bliptext.com/articles/theme-narrative) of death, love, loss, prejudice, coming-of-age, and the loss of innocence in a 1990s British setting.
In Harry Potter, Rowling juxtaposes the extraordinary against the ordinary.
Her narrative features two worlds: a contemporary world inhabited by non-magical people called [Muggles](https://bliptext.com/articles/muggles), and another featuring wizards.
It differs from typical [portal fantasy](https://bliptext.com/articles/portal-fantasy) in that its magical elements stay grounded in the mundane.
Paintings move and talk; books bite readers; letters shout messages; and maps show live journeys, making the wizarding world both exotic and familiar.
This blend of realistic and romantic elements extends to Rowling's characters.
Their names are often [onomatopoeic](https://bliptext.com/articles/onomatopoeic): Malfoy is difficult, Filch is unpleasant, and Lupin is a werewolf.
Harry is ordinary and relatable, with down-to-earth features such as wearing broken glasses; the scholar Roni Natov terms him an "everychild".
These elements serve to highlight Harry when he is heroic, making him both an [everyman](https://bliptext.com/articles/everyman) and a fairytale hero.
Each of the seven books is set over the course of one school year.
Harry struggles with the problems he encounters, and dealing with them often involves the need to violate some school rules.
If students are caught breaking rules, they are often disciplined by Hogwarts professors.
The stories reach their climax in the [summer term](https://bliptext.com/articles/summer-term), near or just after [final exams](https://bliptext.com/articles/final-examination), when events escalate far beyond in-school squabbles and struggles, and Harry must confront either [Voldemort](https://bliptext.com/articles/voldemort) or one of his followers, the [Death Eaters](https://bliptext.com/articles/death-eaters), with the stakes a matter of life and death—a point underlined, as the series progresses, by characters being killed in each of the final four books.
In the aftermath, he learns important lessons through exposition and discussions with head teacher and mentor [Albus Dumbledore](https://bliptext.com/articles/albus-dumbledore).
The only exception to this school-centred setting is the final novel, [Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows), in which Harry and his friends spend most of their time away from Hogwarts, and only return there to face Voldemort at the [dénouement](https://bliptext.com/articles/d-nouement).

## Allusions
The Harry Potter stories feature imagery and motifs drawn from [Arthurian myth](https://bliptext.com/articles/arthurian-myth) and [fairytales](https://bliptext.com/articles/fairytales).
Harry's ability to draw the [Sword of Gryffindor](https://bliptext.com/articles/sword-of-gryffindor) from the [Sorting Hat](https://bliptext.com/articles/sorting-hat) resembles the Arthurian [sword in the stone](https://bliptext.com/articles/excalibur) legend.
His life with the Dursleys has been compared to [Cinderella](https://bliptext.com/articles/cinderella).
Hogwarts resembles a medieval university-cum-castle with several professors who belong to an Order of Merlin; Old Professor Binns still lectures about the International Warlock Convention of 1289; and a real historical person, a 14th-century scribe, Sir [Nicolas Flamel](https://bliptext.com/articles/nicolas-flamel), is described as a holder of the Philosopher's Stone.
Other medieval elements in Hogwarts include coats-of-arms and medieval weapons on the walls, letters written on parchment and sealed with wax, the Great Hall of Hogwarts, which is similar to the Great Hall of Camelot, the use of Latin phrases, the tents put up for Quidditch tournaments, which are similar to the "marvellous tents" put up for knightly tournaments, imaginary animals like dragons and unicorns that exist around Hogwarts, and the banners with heraldic animals for the four Houses of Hogwarts.
Many of the motifs of the Potter stories, such as the hero's quest invoking objects that confer invisibility, magical animals and trees, a forest full of danger and the recognition of a character based upon scars, are drawn from medieval French Arthurian romances.
Other aspects borrowed from French Arthurian romances include the use of owls as messengers, werewolves as characters, and white deer.
The American scholars Heather Arden and Kathrn Lorenz in particular argue that many aspects of the Potter stories are inspired by a 14th-century French Arthurian romance, Claris et Laris, writing of the "startling" similarities between the adventures of Potter and the knight Claris.
Arden and Lorenz noted that Rowling graduated from the University of Exeter in 1986 with a degree in French literature and spent a year living in France afterwards.
Like C. S. Lewis's The Chronicles of Narnia, Harry Potter also contains Christian symbolism and [allegory](https://bliptext.com/articles/allegory).
The series has been viewed as a Christian moral fable in the [psychomachia](https://bliptext.com/articles/psychomachia) tradition, in which stand-ins for good and evil fight for supremacy over a person's soul.
Children's literature critic Joy Farmer sees parallels between Harry and [Jesus Christ](https://bliptext.com/articles/jesus-christ).
Comparing Rowling with Lewis, she argues that "magic is both authors' way of talking about spiritual reality".
According to [Maria Nikolajeva](https://bliptext.com/articles/maria-nikolajeva), Christian imagery is particularly strong in the final scenes of the series: Harry dies in self-sacrifice and Voldemort delivers an "[ecce homo](https://bliptext.com/articles/ecce-homo)" speech, after which Harry is [resurrected](https://bliptext.com/articles/resurrection-of-jesus) and defeats his enemy.
Rowling stated that she did not reveal Harry Potter's religious parallels in the beginning because doing so would have "give[n] too much away to fans who might then see the parallels".
In the final book of the series, [Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows](https://bliptext.com/articles/harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows), Rowling makes the book's Christian imagery more explicit, quoting both [Matthew 6:21](https://bliptext.com/articles/matthew-6-21) and [1 Corinthians 15:26](https://bliptext.com/articles/1-corinthians-15-26) ([King James Version](https://bliptext.com/articles/king-james-version)) when Harry visits his parents' [graves](https://bliptext.com/articles/kirkyard).
[Hermione Granger](https://bliptext.com/articles/hermione-granger) teaches Harry Potter that the meaning of these verses from the [Christian Bible](https://bliptext.com/articles/christian-bible) are "living beyond death. Living after death", which Rowling states "epitomize the whole series".
Rowling also exhibits Christian values in developing Albus Dumbledore as a God-like character, the divine, trusted leader of the series, guiding the long-suffering hero along his quest.
In the seventh novel, Harry speaks with and questions the deceased Dumbledore much like a person of faith would talk to and question God.

# Themes
Harry Potter overarching theme is Comedy
In the first book, when Harry looks into the Mirror of Erised, he feels both joy and "a terrible sadness" at seeing his desire: his parents, alive and with him.
Confronting their loss is central to Harry's character arc and manifests in different ways through the series, such as in his struggles with [Dementors](https://bliptext.com/articles/magical-creatures-in-harry-potter).
Other characters in Harry's life die; he even faces his own death in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.
The series has an [existential](https://bliptext.com/articles/existentialism) perspective—Harry must grow mature enough to accept death.
In Harry's world, death is not binary but mutable, a state that exists in degrees.
Unlike Voldemort, who evades death by separating and hiding his soul in seven parts, Harry's soul is whole, nourished by friendship and love.
Love distinguishes Harry and Voldemort.
Harry is a hero because he loves others, even willing to accept death to save them; Voldemort is a villain because he does not.
Harry carries the protection of his mother's sacrifice in his blood; Voldemort, who wants Harry's blood and the protection it carries, does not understand that love vanquishes death.
Rowling has spoken about thematising death and loss in the series.
Soon after she started writing Philosopher's Stone, her mother died; she said that "I really think from that moment on, death became a central, if not the central theme of the seven books".
Rowling has described Harry as "the prism through which I view death", and further stated that "all of my characters are defined by their attitude to death and the possibility of death".
While Harry Potter can be viewed as a story about good vs. evil, its moral divisions are not absolute.
First impressions of characters are often misleading.
Harry assumes in the first book that Quirrell is on the side of good because he opposes Snape, who appears to be malicious; in reality, Quirrell is an agent of Voldemort, while Snape is loyal to Dumbledore.
This pattern later recurs with Moody and Snape.
In Rowling's world, good and evil are choices rather than inherent attributes: second chances and the possibility of redemption are key themes of the series.
This is reflected in Harry's self-doubts after learning his connections to Voldemort, such as Parseltongue; and prominently in Snape's characterisation, which has been described as complex and multifaceted.
In some scholars' view, while Rowling's narrative appears on the surface to be about Harry, her focus may actually be on Snape's morality and character arc.
Rowling said that, to her, the moral significance of the tales seems "blindingly obvious".
In the fourth book, Dumbledore speaks of a "choice between what is right and what is easy"; Rowling views this as a key theme, "because that ... is how tyranny is started, with people being apathetic and taking the easy route and suddenly finding themselves in deep trouble".
Academics and journalists have developed many other interpretations of themes in the books, some more complex than others, and some including [political subtexts](https://bliptext.com/articles/politics-of-harry-potter).
Themes such as [normality](https://bliptext.com/articles/normality-behavior), oppression, survival, and overcoming imposing odds have all been considered as prevalent throughout the series.
Similarly, the theme of making one's way through adolescence and "going over one's most harrowing ordeals—and thus coming to terms with them" has also been considered.
Rowling has stated that the books comprise "a prolonged argument for tolerance, a prolonged plea for an end to [bigotry](https://bliptext.com/articles/bigotry)" and that they also pass on a message to "question authority and... not assume that the establishment or the press tells you all of the truth".

# Development history
In 1990, Rowling was on a crowded train from [Manchester](https://bliptext.com/articles/manchester) to [London](https://bliptext.com/articles/london) when the idea for Harry suddenly "fell into" her head.
Rowling gives an account of the experience on her website saying:
"I had been writing almost continuously since the age of six but I had never been so excited about an idea before. I simply sat and thought, for four (delayed train) hours, and all the details bubbled up in my brain, and this scrawny, black-haired, bespectacled boy who did not know he was a wizard became more and more real to me."
Rowling completed Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone in 1995 and the [manuscript](https://bliptext.com/articles/manuscript) was sent off to several prospective [agents](https://bliptext.com/articles/literary-agent).
The second agent she tried, [Christopher Little](https://bliptext.com/articles/christopher-little), offered to represent her and sent the manuscript to several publishers.

## Publishing history
After twelve other publishers had rejected Philosopher's Stone, [Bloomsbury](https://bliptext.com/articles/bloomsbury-publishing) agreed to publish the book.
Despite Rowling's statement that she did not have any particular [age group](https://bliptext.com/articles/demographic-profile) in mind when beginning to write the Harry Potter books, the publishers initially targeted children aged nine to eleven.
On the eve of publishing, Rowling was asked by her publishers to adopt a more [gender-neutral](https://bliptext.com/articles/epicenity) pen name in order to appeal to the male members of this age group, fearing that they would not be interested in reading a novel they knew to be written by a woman.
She elected to use J. K. Rowling (Joanne Kathleen Rowling), using her grandmother's name as her second name because she has no [middle name](https://bliptext.com/articles/middle-name).
Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was published by Bloomsbury, the publisher of all Harry Potter books in the United Kingdom, on 26 June 1997.
It was released in the United States on 1 September 1998 by [Scholastic](https://bliptext.com/articles/scholastic-press)—the American publisher of the books—as Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, after the American rights sold for US$105,000—a record amount for a children's book by an unknown author.
Scholastic feared that American readers would not associate the word "philosopher" with magic, and Rowling suggested the title Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone for the American market.
Rowling has later said that she regrets the change.
The second book, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, was originally published in the UK on 2 July 1998 and in the US on 2 June 1999.
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban was published a year later in the UK on 8 July 1999 and in the US on 8 September 1999.
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire was published on 8 July 2000 at the same time by Bloomsbury and Scholastic.
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is the longest book in the series, at 766 pages in the UK version and 870 pages in the US version.
It was published worldwide in English on 21 June 2003.
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince was published on 16 July 2005.
The seventh and final novel, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, was published on 21 July 2007.
Rowling herself has stated that the last chapter of the final book (in fact, the epilogue) was completed "in something like 1990".
Rowling retained rights to digital editions and released them on the Pottermore website in 2012.
Vendors such as Amazon displayed the ebooks in the form of links to Pottermore, which controlled pricing.
All seven Harry Potter novels have been released in unabridged [audiobook](https://bliptext.com/articles/audiobook) versions, with [Stephen Fry](https://bliptext.com/articles/stephen-fry) reading the British editions and [Jim Dale](https://bliptext.com/articles/jim-dale) voicing the series for the American editions.
On [Audible](https://bliptext.com/articles/audible-service), the series has been listened, as of November 2022, for over a billion hours.

## Translations
The series has been translated into more than 80 languages, placing Rowling among the most translated authors in history.
The books have seen translations to diverse languages such as [Korean](https://bliptext.com/articles/korean-language), [Armenian](https://bliptext.com/articles/armenian-language), [Ukrainian](https://bliptext.com/articles/ukrainian-language), [Arabic](https://bliptext.com/articles/arabic-language), [Urdu](https://bliptext.com/articles/urdu-language), [Hindi](https://bliptext.com/articles/hindi-language), [Bengali](https://bliptext.com/articles/bengali-language), [Bulgarian](https://bliptext.com/articles/bulgarian-language), [Welsh](https://bliptext.com/articles/welsh-language), [Afrikaans](https://bliptext.com/articles/afrikaans), [Albanian](https://bliptext.com/articles/albanian-language), [Latvian](https://bliptext.com/articles/latvian-language), [Vietnamese](https://bliptext.com/articles/vietnamese-language) and [Hawaiian](https://bliptext.com/articles/hawaiian-language).
The first volume has been translated into [Latin](https://bliptext.com/articles/latin) and even [Ancient Greek](https://bliptext.com/articles/ancient-greek), making it the longest published work in [Ancient Greek](https://bliptext.com/articles/ancient-greek) since the novels of [Heliodorus of Emesa](https://bliptext.com/articles/heliodorus-of-emesa) in the 3rd century AD. The second volume has also been translated into [Latin](https://bliptext.com/articles/latin).
Some of the translators hired to work on the books were well-known authors before their work on Harry Potter, such as [Viktor Golyshev](https://bliptext.com/articles/viktor-golyshev), who oversaw the Russian translation of the series' fifth book.
The [Turkish](https://bliptext.com/articles/turkish-language) translation of books two to seven was undertaken by [Sevin Okyay](https://bliptext.com/articles/sevin-okyay), a popular literary critic and cultural commentator.
For reasons of secrecy, translation on a given book could only start after it had been released in English, leading to a lag of several months before the translations were available.
This led to more and more copies of the English editions being sold to impatient fans in non-English speaking countries; for example, such was the clamour to read Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix that its English language edition became the first English-language book ever to top the best-seller list in France.
The United States editions were adapted into [American English](https://bliptext.com/articles/american-english) to make them more understandable to a young American audience.
# [The Russian translation of The Deathly Hallows goes on sale in Moscow, 2007 | upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/75/RIAN///archive///168852///The///seventh///book///about///Harry///Potter///goes///on///sale.jpg]

## Cover art
For cover art, Bloomsbury chose painted art in a classic style of design, with the first cover a watercolour and pencil drawing by illustrator [Thomas Taylor](https://bliptext.com/articles/thomas-taylor-artist) showing Harry boarding the Hogwarts Express, and a title in the font [Cochin Bold](https://bliptext.com/articles/cochin-typeface).
The first releases of the successive books in the series followed in the same style but somewhat more realistic, illustrating scenes from the books.
These covers were created by first [Cliff Wright](https://bliptext.com/articles/cliff-wright-illustrator) and then Jason Cockroft.
Due to the appeal of the books among an adult audience, Bloomsbury commissioned a second line of editions in an 'adult' style.
These initially used black-and-white photographic art for the covers showing objects from the books (including a very American Hogwarts Express) without depicting people, but later shifted to partial colourisation with a picture of Slytherin's locket on the cover of the final book.
International and later editions have been created by a range of designers, including [Mary GrandPré](https://bliptext.com/articles/mary-grandpr) for US audiences and [Mika Launis](https://bliptext.com/articles/mika-launis) in Finland.
For a later American release, [Kazu Kibuishi](https://bliptext.com/articles/kazu-kibuishi) created covers in a somewhat anime-influenced style.

# Reception

## Commercial success
The popularity of the Harry Potter series has translated into substantial financial success for Rowling, her publishers, and other Harry Potter related license holders.
This success has made Rowling the first and thus far only billionaire author.
The books have sold more than 600 million copies worldwide and have also given rise to the popular [film adaptations](https://bliptext.com/articles/film-adaptation) produced by [Warner Bros. Pictures](https://bliptext.com/articles/warner-bros-pictures), [all of which have been highly successful in their own right](https://bliptext.com/articles/list-of-highest-grossing-films).
The total revenue from the book sales is estimated, as of November 2018, to be around $7.7 billion.
The first novel in the series, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, has sold in excess of 120 million copies, making it one of the bestselling books in history.
The films have in turn spawned eight video games and have led to the licensing of more than 400 additional Harry Potter products.
The Harry Potter brand has been estimated to be worth as much as $25 billion.
The great demand for Harry Potter novels motivated [The New York Times](https://bliptext.com/articles/the-new-york-times) to create a separate best-seller list for children's literature in 2000, just before the release of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.
By 24 June 2000, Rowling's novels had been on the list for 79 straight weeks; the first three novels were each on the hardcover best-seller list.
On 12 April 2007, [Barnes & Noble](https://bliptext.com/articles/barnes-noble) declared that Deathly Hallows had broken its [pre-order](https://bliptext.com/articles/pre-order) record, with more than 500,000 copies [pre-order](https://bliptext.com/articles/pre-order)ed through its site.
For the release of Goblet of Fire, 9,000 [FedEx](https://bliptext.com/articles/fedex) trucks were used with no other purpose than to deliver the book.
Together, Amazon.com and [Barnes & Noble](https://bliptext.com/articles/barnes-noble) pre-sold more than 700,000 copies of the book.
In the United States, the book's initial printing run was 3.8 million copies.
This record statistic was broken by Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, with 8.5 million, which was then shattered by Half-Blood Prince with 10.8 million copies.
Within the first 24 hours of its release, 6.9 million copies of Prince were sold in the US; in the UK more than two million copies were sold on the first day.
The initial US print run for Deathly Hallows was 12 million copies, and more than a million were pre-ordered through Amazon and Barnes & Noble.
Fans of the series were so eager for the latest instalment that bookstores around the world began holding events to coincide with the midnight release of the books, beginning with the 2000 publication of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.
The events, commonly featuring mock sorting, games, face painting, and other live entertainment have achieved popularity with Potter fans and have been highly successful in attracting fans and selling books with nearly nine million of the 10.8 million initial print copies of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince sold in the first 24 hours.
The final book in the series, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows became the fastest selling book in history, moving 11 million units in the first twenty-four hours of release.
The book sold 2.7 million copies in the UK and 8.3 million in the US.
The series has also gathered adult fans, leading to the release of two editions of each Harry Potter book, identical in text but with one edition's cover artwork aimed at children and the other aimed at adults.
